topics.body: Another term that gets thrown around is the "Golden Age of Film." I hate that phrase soooooooooooo much. It's the nostalgia goggles problem. People, mostly older folks, love to talk about how much better movies were "back in their day" without realizing that there has always been schlock and only the truly good things survive.

topics.author: 5056c9e87f123b37f6012a34

topics.body:
"@mariomarc":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5421dc3c6368723871450000#post_5421dc3c6368723871450000
We're probably going to replace oil in the next ten to fifteen years.  There's algae biofuel being worked on, solar roadways, fusion energy is actually making massive strides, solar cells are far more efficient now than ten years ago, there's experimental prototype cars that use a small combustion engine to power a generator to power the wheels cause it's far more efficient.  Chances are the cars of the future will rely on algae biofuel to power a small engine to run electric motors in car wheels cause if you put in all the loss of power between the engine and the wheels there's a massive drop in efficiency.

Upside: algae biofuel/electric hybrid cars potentially would be far more efficient.
Downside: If you want a super powerful truck capable of running your neighbor's car over and turning it into paste you're out of luck buddy cause that shit's going to be way out of your league financially.

topics.body:
"@mariomarc":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5421dea16368722676a00000#post_5421dea16368722676a00000
The thing people that go "oh we'll always have oil" don't realize is that there's a point at which the cost of production exceeds profits; if you cross this point your industry is fucked.

Right now algae biofuel costs $7/gallon because one of the chemicals to break the cell wall is expensive; if oil went over $7/gallon the entire oil industry would collapse because algae overnight would replace it.  Once they figure out how to make algae biofuel less expensive the entire oil industry is going to collapse overnight; at this point it's a question of when is oil going to become obsolete, not "if".  My money is on less than 10 years.  In 2009 algae biofuel costed $33/gallon.
